citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Lynn's Hope (id#900217000512060,) a female Havanese-Poodle mix dog with 2 puppies (DOB 1/21/24) is very thin. Her
spine, ribs, shoulder blades, hips are easily felt. There is an abdominal tuck. The owner stated that she was giving the
dog milk replacer but has not consulted with a veterinarian about the dog's condition. Significant weight loss or thin body
condition can indicate an underlying medical condition such as stress, illness, parasites and/or poor quality of food. This
dog's abnormal body condition could also negatively affect the growth and health of her puppies. The dog must be
examined by a veterinarian for appropriate diagnosis and treatment.
Lynn's Heidi (id# 900217000511467) a female Havanese-Poodle mix dog had scabby bumps on her neck, back, hips and
ears. The skin was very red on her throat and chest. The owner had bathed her several days ago but the redness and
sores can indicate that there is an underlying condition that the shampoo is not helping. Improperly or untreated skin
conditions can worsen and cause more irritation and potentially become infected. This dog needs to be evaluated by a
veterinarian for proper diagnosis and treatment.
Documentation of diagnoses and treatments must be made available to APHIS officials. The applicant must ensure that
all animals receive adequate veterinary care at all times.
Correction date: 22 February 2024

The current APHIS 7005 Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats on Hand form lists 68 dogs but the actual count of dogs
above 16 weeks of age is 88. Without proper and accurate records of all the dogs, their identity is not known with
certainty, and any dog born, purchased, traded, sold or that leaves by other methods cannot be tracked the dogs
accurately. The APHIS 7005 must be updated to reflect the number of dogs in the facility. It must include all required
information for this section and be maintained at all times

There are 9 stacked cages made of metal bars that have an excessive amount of rust on the vertical and horizontal bars.
Rusty surfaces cannot be sanitized due to pitting and rough surfaces and can cause weakness in the structural strength
of the metal. Interior surfaces and any surfaces that come in contact with dogs must be free of excessive rust that
prevents the required cleaning and sanitization, or that affects the structural strength of the surface. The rusty surfaces
must be repaired or replaced and maintained at all times.

Cement blocks are used as a step into the inside part of the shelter building. The cement blocks have moisture seeping
up their surfaces from the recent washing of the concrete floor on the outside part. There are wooden posts at the end of
each run that have green algae on the lower part of the posts and have moisture on that area also from the recent
washing of the runs. These areas indicate that the wood and cement surfaces are not impervious to moisture. When not
impervious to moisture, the surfaces cannot be properly cleaned and sanitized and may become a source of bacteria,
viruses, mold that may cause illness. These surfaces must be impervious to moisture and maintained at all times.

The exercise plan was not available for review by the inspector. The licensee did not know where it was. A plan to offer
dogs an opportunity for exercise is important for the physical and mental health of the dogs. Dealers must develop,
document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide dogs with the opportunity for exercise. The licensee must develop
the exercise plan and have the veterinarian approve and sign it and it must be maintained and available to APHIS officials
upon request.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
Correct all directs by the date listed above or prior to the next scheduled re-license inspection, whichever comes first.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by April 22, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. An
unannounced inspection to reinspect for the direct(s) may be conducted prior to your next licensing inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. Conducting regulated activity without a
valid USDA license is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Lynn's Hope (id#900217000512060,) a female Havanese-Poodle mix dog with 2 puppies (DOB 1/21/24) is very thin. Her 
spine, ribs, shoulder blades, hips are easily felt. There is an abdominal tuck. The owner stated that she was giving the 
dog milk replacer but has not consulted with a veterinarian about the dog's condition. Significant weight loss or thin body 
condition can indicate an underlying medical condition such as stress, illness, parasites and/or poor quality of food. This 
dog's abnormal body condition could also negatively affect the growth and health of her puppies. The dog must be 
examined by a veterinarian for appropriate diagnosis and treatment.  
 
Lynn's Heidi (id# 900217000511467) a female Havanese-Poodle mix dog had scabby bumps on her neck, back, hips and 
ears. The skin was very red on her throat and chest. The owner had bathed her several days ago but the redness and 
sores can indicate that there is an underlying condition that the shampoo is not helping. Improperly or untreated skin 
conditions can worsen and cause more irritation and potentially become infected. This dog needs to be evaluated by a 
veterinarian for proper diagnosis and treatment.  
 
Documentation of diagnoses and treatments must be made available to APHIS officials. The applicant must ensure that 
all animals receive adequate veterinary care at all times.  
 
Correction date: 22 February 2024 
2.75(a)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The current APHIS 7005 Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats on Hand form lists 68 dogs but the actual count of dogs 
above 16 weeks of age is 88. Without proper and accurate records of all the dogs, their identity is not known with 
certainty, and any dog born, purchased, traded, sold or that leaves by other methods cannot be tracked the dogs 
accurately. The APHIS 7005 must be updated to reflect the number of dogs in the facility. It must include all required 
information for this section and be maintained at all times 
3.1(c)(1)(i) 
   
Housing facilities, general.

There are 9 stacked cages made of metal bars that have an excessive amount of rust on the vertical and horizontal bars. 
Rusty surfaces cannot be sanitized due to pitting and rough surfaces and can cause weakness in the structural strength 
of the metal. Interior surfaces and any surfaces that come in contact with dogs must be free of excessive rust that 
prevents the required cleaning and sanitization, or that affects the structural strength of the surface. The rusty surfaces 
must be repaired or replaced and maintained at all times. 
3.3(e)(1) 
   
Sheltered housing facilities. 
Cement blocks are used as a step into the inside part of the shelter building. The cement blocks have moisture seeping 
up their surfaces from the recent washing of the concrete floor on the outside part. There are wooden posts at the end of 
each run that have green algae on the lower part of the posts and have moisture on that area also from the recent 
washing of the runs. These areas indicate that the wood and cement surfaces are not impervious to moisture. When not 
impervious to moisture, the surfaces cannot be properly cleaned and sanitized and may become a source of bacteria, 
viruses, mold that may cause illness. These surfaces must be impervious to moisture and maintained at all times. 
3.8 
   
Exercise for dogs. 
The exercise plan was not available for review by the inspector. The licensee did not know where it was. A plan to offer 
dogs an opportunity for exercise is important for the physical and mental health of the dogs. Dealers must develop, 
document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide dogs with the opportunity for exercise. The licensee must develop 
the exercise plan and have the veterinarian approve and sign it and it must be maintained and available to APHIS officials 
upon request. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 Correct all directs by the date listed above or prior to the next scheduled re-license inspection, whichever comes first.  
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by April 22, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. An 
unannounced inspection to reinspect for the direct(s) may be conducted prior to your next licensing inspection.  
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. Conducting regulated activity without a 
valid USDA license is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
